questions.question:
Question 1: A 50-year-old woman underwent a screening colonoscopy. A single polyp is found, resected, 
and sent for histopathological examination. Which of the following biopsy findings will have 
the highest risk of malignancy?
questions.explanation:
Villous adenoma has the highest risk of malignancy. Adenomatous polyps can be tubular, tubulovillous, and villous adenomas. Among these, tubular 
adenoma has the least risk and villous adenoma has the highest risk of malignancy.

questions.question:
Question 2: During a colonoscopy on a 58-year-old female patient, a smooth nodular polyp is found and 
excised. The microscopic image is given. Choose the incorrect statement regarding the polyp.

options.c: Usually seen in the 6th and 7th decade of life
options.d: Malignant transformation takes place within 5 years

questions.explanation:
Hyperplastic polyps, as seen in the histological picture, do not have malignant potential. Elongated crypts, i.e., serrated (saw-toothed) or star-shaped appearance, is a characteristic feature 
of a hyperplastic polyp. They are the most common type of colorectal polyps and are usually seen in the 6th and 7th 
decade of life. More than 90% occur in rectosigmoid region.

questions.question:
Question 3: The biopsy of a polyp reported dysplasia up to the colonic submucosa. Classify this lesion 
using Haggitt's classification:
questions.explanation: According to Haggitt’s classification, a polyp invading the submucosa comes under level 4.

questions.question:
Question 4: A 35-year-old patient undergoes a screening colonoscopy after his brother was diagnosed with 
colorectal cancer. Which of the following, if detected, does not indicate a risk of developing 
colon cancer?

options.a: Villous adenomas in the ascending colon
options.b: More than 100 polyps in the transverse and descending colon
options.c: Inflammatory polyps in the sigmoid colon and rectum
options.d: Sessile serrated adenomatous polyps in the sigmoid colon

questions.explanation:
Inflammatory polyps are not premalignant. 576 
Sold by @itachibot Inflammatory polyps (pseudopolyps) are found in cases of: • Inflammatory bowel disease (most common) • Amebic colitis • Ischemic colitis • Schistosomal colitis Microscopic examination shows islands of normal, regenerating mucosa (the polyp) surrounded 
by areas of mucosal loss.

questions.question:
Question 5: A 12-year-old is brought to the emergency with features of intestinal obstruction. An 
ultrasound reveals a target sign, suggesting intussusception. On closer examination, her palm 
and oral mucosa are spotted with multiple 1-2 mm blue-gray macules. What is the most likely 
diagnosis? 564 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
The patient most likely has Peutz–Jeghers syndrome. It is characterized by hamartomatous polyps of the intestinal tract (more commonly small 
intestine) and hyperpigmentation of the buccal mucosa, lips, and digits. In the given clinical 
scenario, the patient has had an intestinal intussusception. The numerous polyps in Peutz-Jeghers 
syndrome often serve as a lead point. Option A: Turcot syndrome constitutes colorectal polyps and brain tumors (including cerebellar 
medulloblastoma and glioblastomas) Option B: Lynch syndrome is also called hereditary nonpolyposis colon cancer (HNPCC). It is due 
to defective mismatch repair (MMR) of DNA. Option D: Cowden syndrome is characterized by polyps of the stomach or colon, macrocephaly 
and benign tumors of thyroid, breast, and uterus.

questions.question:
Question 6: Ophthalmoscopy performed on a 14-year-old boy had the given incidental finding. Family 
history revealed that his grandfather had colon cancer and an aunt was diagnosed with 
endometrial carcinoma. Genetic testing confirmed APC gene mutation. Which of the 
following is false about his condition? 565 
Sold by @itachibot

options.a: Condition can be passed on to his daughter in the future
options.b: Mutation of APC gene is on chromosome 15

questions.explanation:
577 
Sold by @itachibot The given image showing a pigmented retina, the patient's family history and APC gene mutation 
is suggestive of familial adenomatous polyposis. Familial adenomatous polyposis is due to 
the mutation of APC gene located on the long arm of chromosome 5 (5q21), not 15. Familial adenomatous polyposis (FAP) is autosomal dominant. It is characterized by the presence 
of >100 adenomatous polyps in colon and rectum. It usually manifests by the late 2nd or early 
3rd decade. Although it accounts for 1% of all colorectal carcinoma, the risk of development of 
cancer is 100%. CHRPE (Congenital hypertrophy of retinal pigment epthelium) is the earliest extra-colonic 
manifestation of FAP, present in up to 75% of patients.

questions.question: Question 7: All of the following are gastrointestinal manifestations seen in patients with FAP except:

options.b: Fundal gland hyperplasia in gastric polyp

questions.explanation:
Esophageal carcinoma is not associated with FAP Familial adenomatous polyposis (FAP) is associated with gastric and duodenal polyps in 
approximately 50% of the affected individuals. Most of the gastric polyps represent fundic gland hyperplasia and have limited malignant 
potential. Duodenal polyps are adenomatous in nature and premalignant. Patients with FAP have an increased risk for duodenal ampullary cancer.

questions.question: Question 8: Which of the following is not a component of Gardner's syndrome?
questions.explanation: Gardner’s syndrome does not include brain tumors. Components of Gardner’s syndrome: • Osteomas: most common manifestation, most commonly in the mandible • Polyposis colon • Dental anomalies (supernumerary tooth, absent tooth, impacted tooth) • Epidermal inclusion cysts • Desmoid tumors Note: Turcot’s syndrome includes brain tumor and colorectal polyps.

questions.question: Question 9: Which of the following is the most common presentation of abdominal desmoid tumor?
questions.explanation:
Explanation: The most common presentation of an abdominal desmoid tumor is an abdominal mass. 578 
Sold by @itachibot Desmoid tumors, also known as fibromatosis, aggressive fibromatosis or desmoid-type 
fibromatosis are locally aggressive tumors that lack metastatic potential. Desmoid tumors can be 
sporadic in origin or associated with familial adenomatous polyposis. These tumors arise from fibro-aponeurotic tissue and typically are manifested as a slowly growing 
mass. They present as firm, non-painful, non-tender masses in the abdominal wall, shoulder, hip 
and limbs, mesentery, and pelvis. They are also associated with trauma, pregnancy, and oral 
contraceptive usage. The investigation of choice for a desmoid tumor is MRI. It is superior to CT in defining the 
pattern and the extent of involvement and can determine recurrence after surgery. Diagnosis is 
established by a biopsy with immunohistochemistry, which stains positive for beta-catenin, actin 
and vimentin, and negative for desmin, cytokeratin and S-100. Treatment: • An initial observation is preferred for stable, asymptomatic, primary or recurrent desmoids, 
especially if surgery can cause high mortality. • Surgical resection with negative margin clearance is reserved for patients with small abdominal 
wall tumors associated with pain or an increase in size. • Tamoxifen and NSAIDs are used as first-line medical therapy. Other systemic treatment options 
are low-dose chemotherapy, tyrosinase kinase inhibitors, and full-dose chemotherapy • Radiotherapy is preferred for candidates unfit for surgery, patients refusing surgery and when 
surgical resection is associated with high morbidity.

questions.question:
Question 10: A 29-year-old man was brought to the hospital with a history of headache and vomiting for 
the past 7 days and an episode of a tonic-clonic seizure. The image of the MRI scan is shown 
below. Colonoscopy revealed numerous polyps in the colon and the rectum which were found 566 
Sold by @itachibot to be adenomatous on biopsy. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
In the given clinical scenario, the patient has numerous adenomatous polyps and a tumor in the 
brain. Therefore the most likely diagnosis is Turcot's syndrome. It is a variant of familial 
adenomatous polyposis. Familial adenomatous polyposis (FAP) is an autosomal dominant condition and is caused due to 
the mutation in the APC gene located on chromosome 5. Clinically, patients develop hundreds to thousands of adenomatous polyps in the colon and 
rectum. Some patients may also develop duodenal adenomas. The lifetime risk of developing 
colorectal carcinoma in these patients is 100%. The treatment of the FAP includes total proctocolectomy with ileal pouch-anal anastomosis 
(IPAA). Variants of FAP are: • Gardner's syndrome- It is an autosomal dominant variant of FAP. In addition to colonic polyps 
the patients will have • Osteomas of the mandible or skull • Epidermal cysts • Soft tissue tumors like desmoid tumor 579 
Sold by @itachibot • Turcot's syndrome- In addition to the colonic polyps the patients will have central nervous 
system tumors (primary brain tumors). Option D: Peutz-Jegher's syndrome is not related to familial adenomatous polyposis. It is an 
autosomal dominant disease characterized by • Pigmentation of the mouth and lips • Multiple hamartomatous polyps in the small and large intestine.

questions.question:
Question 11: Colonoscopy and biopsy on a 35-year-old man revealed hundreds of adenomatous polyps in 
the entire descending and sigmoid colon. Options for prophylactic surgery are discussed. 
Which of the following procedures will reduce the occurrence of malignancy the most?

options.b: Total colectomy with ileal pouch-anal anastomosis
options.c: Total proctocolectomy with ileal pouch-anal anastomosis

questions.explanation:
The clinical scenario is diagnostic of familial adenomatous polyposis syndrome. To prevent an 
occurrence of cancer, total proctocolectomy with ileal pouch-anal anastomosis is the management 
of choice. This procedure is usually accompanied by resection of the rectal mucosa. Following surgery, the patient has to be routinely followed up for ileoanal-pouch surveillance. 
Upper GI endoscopy should also be performed to evaluate for the presence of duodenal 
adenomas.

questions.question:
Question 12: A 40-year-old man was recently diagnosed and treated for an autosomal dominant disorder. 
The gross specimen of his resected colon is given in the image. What is the initial step in 
screening his 9-year-old child? 567 
Sold by @itachibot

options.a: Genetic testing for APC gene mutation
options.b: Genetic testing for MSH-6 gene mutation
options.c: Routine flexible sigmoidoscopy starting from 10 years of age
options.d: Routine colonoscopy starting from 10 years of age

questions.explanation:
More than 100 colonic polyps are diagnostic of familial adenomatous polyposis syndrome and 
the initial step in screening the child syndrome is to perform genetic testing for APC gene 
mutation. If screening is positive, flexible sigmoidoscopy or colonoscopy is done annually starting from 10 
years of age. If the APC testing is negative, then the risk of developing colorectal carcinoma in the relative is 
similar to the general population. The screening can be started from 50 years of age.

questions.question: Question 13: Which among the following is true about Amsterdam criteria?

options.b: At least 2 or more first-degree relatives affected
options.c: At least one case diagnosed before 50 years of age

questions.explanation:
According to the Amsterdam criteria for hereditary nonpolyposis colorectal cancer (HNPCC), at 
least one case should be diagnosed before 50 years of age. Option A: According to the Amsterdam criteria for a presumptive diagnosis of HNPCC, at least 2 
(not 3) successive generations should be affected. Option B: According to the Amsterdam criteria for a presumptive diagnosis of HNPCC, at least 
3 relatives (not 2) with at least one being first-degree relatives should be affected.

questions.question: Question 14: What is the most common extra-colonic cancer in patients with a mutation in MMR genes?
questions.explanation:
580 
Sold by @itachibot Endometrial carcinoma is the most common extracolonic carcinoma in patients with mutated 
MMR genes. Autosomal dominant mutation in DNA mismatch repair (MMR) genes, such as hMLH1, hMSH2, 
hMSH6, PMS1, and PMS2 lead to various cancers. This condition is known as Lynch 
Syndrome/HNPCC. Gastric and ovarian carcinoma are also commonly found.

questions.question: Question 15: Which among the following is false about colorectal carcinoma in HNPCC?

options.a: The onset of cancer occurs early
options.b: The progression of the carcinoma is slow
options.c: Mucinous adenocarcinoma is the most common type
options.d: Tumors predominantly develop in right sided colon

questions.explanation:
In hereditary nonpolyposis colorectal cancer (HNPCC), there is accelerated tumor progression and 
normal tumor initiation. Accelerated tumor initiation is seen in familial adenomatous polyposis (FAP). In Hereditary Non-polyposis Colorectal Cancer (HNPCC), the onset of cancer is at a relatively 
young age (mean, 44 years). Proximal distribution is more common and nearly 70% of cancers are 
located in the right colon. Mucinous or poorly differentiated (signet cell) adenocarcinoma 
predominate. There is an increased number of synchronous and metachronous cancers. 
The outcome after surgery is relatively good. 581 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 16: A 25-year-old man presented to the dermatologist's office with multiple small bumps on his 
forehead. Excisional biopsy findings are suggestive of multiple small sebaceous adenomas. 
Detailed family history reveals that his grandfather and brother have colon cancer while his 
aunt was diagnosed with rectal cancer. Which syndrome should be suspected?
questions.explanation:
Multiple cutaneous sebaceous adenomas and a family history of various cancers are seen in 
Muir–Torre syndrome. Muir–Torre variant of hereditary nonpolyposis colorectal cancer (HNPCC) may have: • Sebaceous adenomas • Keratoacanthomas • Sebaceous epitheliomas • Basal cell epitheliomas

questions.question: Question 17: Which criteria is used to select patients for microsatellite instability (MSI) testing?
questions.explanation:
Bethesda criteria is used to select patients for microsatellite instability testing. Microsatellites are regions of repeated DNA that change in length (show instability) when 
mismatch repair is not functioning. Defects in mismatch repair genes (as in Lynch 
syndrome/HNPCC) leads to microsatellite instability. Amsterdam criteria is used for a presumptive diagnosis of HNPCC in a family. Because the 
Amsterdam criteria do not include some patients with known germline MMR gene mutations, 
another set of guidelines, known as the Bethesda guidelines, was established to help decide 
whether or not a patient should undergo further molecular testing to rule out HNPCC.

questions.question: Question 18: In which part of the colon does colorectal carcinoma most commonly develop?
questions.explanation:
582 
Sold by @itachibot In the colon, colorectal carcinoma most commonly develops in the sigmoid colon. Overall, the most common site of colorectal carcinoma is the rectum. The sites of development of colorectal carcinoma in order of frequency are: • Rectum • Sigmoid colon • Caecum • Transverse colon • Ascending colon • Descending colon • Splenic flexure • Hepatic flexure

questions.question: Question 19: Which of the following are risk factors for colon carcinoma?
questions.explanation:
Ulcerative colitis, familial adenomatous polyposis (FAP), cholecystectomy, ureterosigmoidostomy, 
and smoking are risk factors for colon cancer.

questions.question:
Question 20: Which of the following dietary recommendation puts patients at risk of developing colon 
cancer?
questions.explanation:
High-calorie, low-fiber, and high-animal-fat diet as well as alcohol consumption increase the risk 
of colon cancer. Calcium, selenium, vitamins A, C, and E, carotenoids, and plant phenols are protective. 583 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 21: Which of the following colonoscopic findings has the highest risk of developing colorectal 
cancer?
questions.explanation:
Sessile/flat polyps are at a higher risk of malignancy compared to pedunculated polyps. Multiple 
polyps increase the risk of malignancy. The probability of development of malignancy of a polyp depends on the following: • Gross appearance of lesion: Sessile polyps are at higher risk for malignancy than pedunculated 
tumors. • Histology: Villous > Tubulovillous > tubular • Size: Polyps of size >2 cm are at higher risk.

questions.question: Question 22: Mutations in which gene is responsible for malignant changes in late colonic adenomas?
questions.explanation:
p53 mutation is responsible for the transformation of late adenoma to carcinoma. The earliest mutations in the adenoma-carcinoma sequence occur in the APC gene and the earliest 
phenotypic change is known as aberrant crypt formation. The most consistent genetic aberrations within these cells abnormally result in the formation of 
short proteins known as APC truncations. They occur in the mutational cluster region of the gene, 
an area responsible for -catenin binding.

questions.question:
Question 23: Which of the following is the correctly matched set regarding risk category and colon cancer 
screening recommendation?
questions.explanation:
Option A states the correctly matched pairs regarding risk category and colon cancer screening

Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 24: A 61-year-old man presents with complaints of fatigue and shortness of breath. He has 
conjunctival pallor and has lost significant weight over 3 months. A CBC reveals low 
haemoglobin and MCV. A stool occult blood test is positive. What is the next best step in 
evaluation?
questions.explanation:
The clinical scenario of an elderly patient with sudden onset anemia always warrants screening for 
colorectal cancer, as cancers in the right colon often manifest as melena and fatigue associated 
with anemia. Thus, the next best investigation is a colonoscopy. Colonoscopy is the investigation of choice & gold standard for establishing the diagnosis of 
colon cancer. It permits biopsy of the tumor to verify the diagnosis while allowing inspection of the entire colon 
to exclude metachronous polyps or cancers. Colonoscopy is generally performed even after cancer is detected by barium enema, in order to 
obtain a biopsy specimen and to detect (and remove) small polyps that may have been missed in 
the contrast study.

questions.question:
Question 25: A 55-year-old woman presents with abdominal pain and constipation. A barium enema 
reveals an apple core sign. In which part of the colon is such a growth commonly seen?
questions.explanation:
Apple core sign on barium enema is suggestive of a constricting type of colon cancer that is more 
common on the left side. Ulcerative type is more common on the right side. Most patients with left-sided colon cancers often present with increasing constipation while 
patients with right-sided colon cancer often present with melena and fatigue associated with 
anemia. The apple core sign describes a short segment irregular circumferential stricture of the large 
bowel that has abrupt shouldered margins resembling an apple core. 585 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 26: What is the most common presenting feature in patients with right sided colon cancer ? 571 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
Anemia is the most common presenting feature in patients with right-sided colon cancer. Cancers in the right colon are more often manifested as melena, fatigue associated with anemia, 
or abdominal pain (if the tumor is advanced). Cancer of the left colon mainly presents with altered bowel habits, usually constipation and 
intestinal obstruction.

questions.question:
Question 27: Which among the following statements is false about virtual colonoscopy as compared to 
conventional colonoscopy?

options.a: Virtual colonoscopy is less sensitive for small polyps
options.b: Provids a better image than conventional colonoscopy
options.c: Easier to take tissue biopsy during virtual colonoscopy
options.d: Less time consuming than conventional colonoscopy

questions.explanation: Virtual colonoscopy is a non-invasive technique and is not useful in taking biopsy.

questions.question:
Question 28: A 50-year-old female presented with low-grade fever, easy fatiguability, and pain in the right 
hypochondrium. On examination, pallor and moderate hepatomegaly were present. A CT 
scan revealed non-enhancing masses. The biopsy showed adenocarcinoma, not of hepatic 
origin. A combination of IHC tests was done and was reported as CK 7 (-), CK20 (+). Which of 
the following is the most likely primary site of origin?
questions.explanation:
Colorectal carcinoma is the most likely primary tumor for the given metastases. Among the given 
options, cytokeratin 7 is negative only in colon carcinoma. The most common site of distant metastasis from colorectal cancer is the liver. These metastases 
arise from hematogenous spread via the portal venous system.The lung is the next most common 
site for metastasis. Cytokeratin profiles of various primary tumors: CK 7 positiveCK20 positive

questions.question: Question 29: What is the most important prognostic factor in patients with colorectal carcinoma?
questions.explanation:
The most important determinant of prognosis for colorectal carcinoma is the tumour stage and, in 
particular, lymph node status. The T-stage (depth of invasion) is the single most significant 
predictor of lymph node spread. 586 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 30: Choose the parameters used to stage colorectal carcinoma according to Duke's classification ?
questions.explanation: Duke’s classification is based on the depth of tumor and lymph node status.

questions.question:
Question 31: The biopsy of a hemicolectomy specimen revealed an adenocarcinoma with colonic subserosa 
invasion. Deposits were found on the mesentery but lymph nodes were not involved. Further 
investigation on the patient did not indicate local or distant metastases. What is the stage of 
the tumor ?
questions.explanation:
According to 8th American Joint Committee on Cancer (AJCC) classification of colorectal cancers, 
tumor deposits in the subserosa or mesentery are staged as N1c and tumor invading the subserosa 
without involvement of peritonealized organs is T3. TNM staging

questions.question: Question 32: Match the following patients with colon cancer to the procedure that is best suited.
questions.explanation:
All of the given procedures may be performed in a patient with colonic cancer presenting with 
features of left colonic obstruction. The most appropriate answer is 1-B,2-C,3-A. In Hartmann's procedure, the segment of the colon containing the obstructing cancer is resected 
and closure of the distal sigmoid or rectum is performed. A colostomy is made. Later, intestinal 
continuity is re-established by the closure of the colostomy and fashioning a colorectal 
anastomosis. 588 
Sold by @itachibot This procedure is preferred in patients when a resection and primary anastomosis cannot be 
performed immediately due to complications such as inflammation of the bowel, perforation, or 
peritonitis. Resection and primary anastomosis is done in patients who are hemodynamically stable and have 
pliable, nonedematous, well-vascularized bowel. In this procedure, the segment of the left colon containing the cancer is resected. The remaining 
colon is cleaned with saline lavage by inserting a catheter through the appendix or ileum into the 
cecum and irrigating the contents from the colon. Primary anastomosis between the prepared 
colon and rectum is fashioned subsequently, without the need for a temporary colostomy Stent placement via colonoscope is a temporary measure to obtain time for bowel preparation for 
primary anastomosis. A stent that traverses the tumor is placed to relieve the obstruction. It is 
done in partial obstruction and is preferred in old and frail patients.

questions.question:
Question 33: A 60-year-old man was rushed to the ER with abdominal pain, obstipation, and altered 
mental status for the last 2 days. Physical examination and imaging findings are suggestive of 
perforated intestinal obstruction with peritonitis. After stabilization, he is immediately taken 
to the operating room, where a suspicious ascending colon mass is seen. Which of the 
following is the most appropriate management for this patient?
questions.explanation:
The elderly man with ascending colon mass leading to perforated intestinal obstruction with 
peritonitis should ideally be treated with right hemicolectomy and ileocolostomy. In case of suspected colorectal cancer presenting with intestinal obstruction the following 
surgeries are done: • Right-sided lesion: • A resection (right hemicolectomy) and anastomosis if the patient is stable • Perforation with substantial contamination or if the patient is unstable: right hemicolectomy + 
ileocolostomy • Left-sided lesion: • Resection and anastomosis if the patient is stable • Perforation with substantial contamination or if the patient is unstable: Hartmann procedure is 
done. Later, intestinal continuity is re-established by the closure of the colostomy and fashioning 
a colorectal anastomosis. • Where endoscopic and radiological facilities are present an obstructing left-sided lesion can be 
treated with an expanding metal stent provided bowel perforation is absent.

questions.question:
Question 34: A 45-year-old man is diagnosed with stage II colorectal carcinoma located in the transverse 
colon. Which of the following is the surgical procedure of choice for this patient?
questions.explanation:
Extended right hemicolectomy is the most appropriate surgical procedure for a neoplastic tumor 
in the transverse colon. This procedure involves resection of the • Terminal ileum with Ileocecal junction • Cecum • Ascending colon 589 
Sold by @itachibot • Hepatic flexure, and • Distal transverse colon Very small and localized lesions in the transverse colon may be resected by transverse colectomy. 
However, this procedure is very uncommon. Tumor location 
Procedure of choice

Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 35: A male patient presented with dull abdominal pain and rectal bleeding. On investigations, he 
was diagnosed with colon carcinoma. Which of the following statements is false regarding the 
management of colorectal carcinoma?

options.a: Stage III cancer is treated with surgical resection and chemotherapy
options.b: Stage II cancer with young age is an indication for chemotherapy
options.c: FOLFOX regimen is used for colorectal carcinoma
options.d: Immunotherapy is ineffective in metastatic colorectal carcinoma

questions.explanation:
Immunotherapy is not ineffective in metastatic colorectal cancer. Metastatic or recurrent 
colorectal cancers are the indications for immunotherapy. Monoclonal antibodies such as • Bevacizumab (Anti-VEGF), • Cetuximab (anti-EGFR), • Panitumumab (anti-EGFR), • Pembrolizumab (anti-PDL1), • Nivolumab (anti-PDL), etc. are the commonly used immunotherapeutic drugs in colorectal 
carcinoma. Option A: Surgical resection is indicated in all the stages of colon carcinoma. Management of 
Stage III colorectal carcinoma should also include chemotherapy, in addition to surgical resection. 
The stage-specific therapies are as follows: Option B: Stage II cancer in young patients should be considered for chemotherapy. Treatment of 
stage II colon carcinoma is surgical resection of the cancerous mass. Adjuvant chemotherapy is 
indicated in patients with at least one poor prognostic indicator like: • Young patients • Inadequate lymph node excision(<12 lymph nodes) • Poorly differentiated histology • Positive margin of resection • T4 lesions • Bowel obstruction or perforation 591 
Sold by @itachibot • Presence of perineural or lymphovascular invasion Option C: FOLFOX is a chemotherapy regimen used for the treatment of colorectal cancer, made 
up of the drugs folinic acid, 5-fluorouracil, and oxaliplatin. Stage 
Management Stage I: 
Surgical resection Stage II:

questions.question: Question 36: Which of the following is a false statement regarding different types of artificial stoma?
questions.explanation:
Colostomy formed during the Hartmann procedure is not a loop colostomy. It is an example of 
end-colostomy. Artificial stomas are surgically created openings on the abdominal wall following certain types of 
surgeries, to serve as an alternate path for internal organs to drain externally. Ileostomy and 
colostomy are the two most common types of artificial stomas for the GI system. Based on the structural pattern, stomas can be classified into different types: • End stoma • Loop stoma • Double barrel stoma End stoma is preferred as a permanent stoma. Loop and double barrel stomas are used as 
temporary stomas. Complications of stoma include • Skin excoriation (most common) • Stoma infection • Diarrhea • Stoma leakage • Parastomal herniation 592
